required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Low-dose Ketamine and Postpartum Depression in Parturients With Prenatal Depression
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Intraoperative Low-dose Ketamine on Incidence of Postpartum Depression in Parturients With Prenatal Depression Undergoing Cesarean Delivery: a Double-blind, Randomized, Placebo-controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Postpartum depression is common in mothers early after childbirth and produces harmful effects not only on mothers, but also on infants and young children. Parturients with prenatal depression are at increased of postpartum depression. Low-dose ketamine can be used for antidepressant therapy. We hypothesize that low-dose ketamine has a therapeutic effect on parturients with prenatal depression. This study is designed to investigate whether low-dose ketamine administered during cesarean delivery can decrease the incidence of postpartum depression in parturients with prenatal depression.

detailed_description.textblock:
Postpartum depression refers to maternal depression developed early after childbirth, with reported incidences varied from 15% to 20%. The development of postpartum depression produces harmful effects not only on mothers, but also on infants and young children. Prenatal depression or high depression score is an independent risk factor for the development of postpartum depression.
Ketamine is commonly used as an general anesthetic. In addition, low-dose ketamine is recommended for antidepressant therapy. We hypothesize that low-dose ketamine has a therapeutic effect on parturients with prenatal depression. However, evidences in this aspect are insufficient. The purpose of this study is to investigate whether low-dose ketamine administered during cesarean delivery can decrease the incidence of postpartum depression in parturients with prenatal depression.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: The score of postpartum depression at 48 hous after childbirth.
primary_outcome.description: Postpartum depression is assessed with Edinburgh postnatal depression scale (EPDS) at 48 hours after childbirth. The EPDS is a 10-item self-rating post-natal depression scale. Each item is scored from 0 to 3, resulting an overall score ranging from 0-30; a high score indicates severe depression.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From delivery to 24 hours after delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: The proportion of neonates with breast feeding.
secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of neonates with breast feeding.

secondary_outcome.measure: Duration of neonatal sleep within 24 hours after delivery.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the first 24 hours after delivery.
secondary_outcome.description: Duration of neonatal sleep within 24 hours after delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: Length of stay in hospital after delivery.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From childbirth up to 30 days after delivery.
secondary_outcome.description: Length of stay in hospital after delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: The score of postpartum depression at 42 days after delivery.
secondary_outcome.description: Postpartum depression is assessed with EPDS at 42 days after childbirth.

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of postpartum depression at 42 days after delivery.
secondary_outcome.description: Postpartum depression is assessed with EPDS at 42 days after childbirth. A EPDS score of 10 or above is defined as postpartum depression.

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of maternal complications with 42 days after delivery.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From childbirth up to 42 days after delivery.
secondary_outcome.description: Incidence of maternal complications with 42 days after delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of neonatal complications with 42 days after delivery.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From childbirth up to 42 days after delivery.
secondary_outcome.description: Incidence of neonatal complications with 42 days after delivery.

arm_group.description: Low-dose ketamine (0.5 mg/kg in 50 ml normal saline) is intravenously infused in 40 minutes after childbirth during cesarean delivery.
Placebo (50 ml normal saline) is intravenously infused in 40 minutes after childbirth during cesarean delivery.

intervention.description: Ketamine (0.5 mg/kg in 50 ml normal saline) will be administered by intravenous infusion in 40 minutes after childbirth during cesarean delivery.
Placebo (50 ml normal saline) will be administered by intravenous infusion in 40 minutes after childbirth during cesarean delivery.

facility.name: Department of Anesthesiology and Critical Care Medicine, Peking University First Hospital
